text: anticipated  travel disruption to employees assigned to toromocho project employees assigned to toromocho project were advised about heavy rain and flooding on route to/from worksite which had blocked temporarly the main road.   mitigations measures are follows:  employees are constantly engaged with gs representaive to ensure that the route is clear prior to departure. monitor the national meteorology and hydrology service (senamhi) and national institute of civil defence (indeci)  for up-to-date information on weather conditions. only daytime movements are permitted. six essentials have been reinforced as well.

category: head or face injury, slips & trips
text: wood employee took his vehicle out of park when his foot slipped off the brakes causing the vehicle to roll into the rail. there were no injuries as a result of the incident. migrated from legacy cairs incident #38567wood employee was in the process of taking his vehicle out of park when his foot slipped off the brakes causing the vehicle to roll into the rail. this caused damage to the radiator, grill and passenger side door. there were no other parties involved at the time of the incident.jsa was performed by employee.weather conditions at the time of the incident was clear and humid.there were no injuries as a result of the incident. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

welder went to clinic stating that he burned left little finger due to radiation. welder stated that he burned his left little finger due to radiation, this happened during the welding test. however the welder went only after 48h to the contractor clinic. worker left the project

ev7800 daily checks not carried out  bp operational team leader (otl) suspected that ev7800 daily checks were not getting carried out properly by the afw shift technician so he retained the key to the ev7800 cage on thursday 12th and saturday 14th january. please note: a key is required to carry out the necessary checks, the checks cannot be done from outside the cage. no request for the key was made during those two days thus no checks could have been made. there is only one key available to access the cage. on sunday 15th the otl had a discussion with the shift technician regarding how the checks are made. the technician advised he had done the checks on those days. the otl challenged that the lamp test can only be done from within the cage & he admitted the daily checks had not been carried out.  the otl re-emphasised the importance of these daily checks as ev7800 was a critical piece of equipment to fps & these checks are part of our early warning for areas of concern to be remediated. the technician apologised and took on board the points the otl raised & committed to carrying these out as per request in future.afw investigation team mobilised. awaiting completion.

driver and passenger were driving to their hotel, and were rear-ended by another driver. roads were wet, and the other driver swerved to avoid them and hit them with a glancing blow.  minimal damage; auto drivable. no one injured. migrated from legacy cairs incident #31361james foster (driver) and dawn tolbert (passenger) were driving to their hotel, and were rear-ended by another driver. roads were wet, and the other driver swerved to avoid them and hit them with a glancing blow. car has minimal damage, and is drivable. nobody was injured. driverwas driving down a road in kingsport, tn in a rental car with dawn tolbert. we were looking for a good spot to make a u-turn to get to the other side of the road. i slowed down to prepare to turn left and i was hit from behind by another vehicle. the police came and supplied an incident report.police report was filed. incident #16-020191. enterprise rental car has been notified of incident. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

lower back pain after sliding heavy machinery  employee slid ponar on controlled surface of a lobster boat during a field assignment on the penobscot river to collect sediment samples.  while sliding the equipment, employee felt a sudden sharp stabbing pain in the lower back.   workcare was consulted and they provided first-aid, self-care advise.  no additional treatment required.

category: hydraulic fluid or oil leak, fuel spill or leak
text: spill of hydraulic oil from a  it-62 loader due to burst hyd hose what happened: at 14:40 today there was a spill of hydraulic oil from a  it-62 loader which was being operated at kopiandia facility, due to burst hyd hose.how much:approx. 500ml of hydraulic fluid reached grade. the contaminated area was cleaned up and disposed of immediately by spill pads and spill kit bags.mechanic to attend scene to rectify equipment.

lo leak on lp compressor the sampling was undertaken using a routine permit by the lead mechanical commissioning technician who was wearing the correct ppe (goggles and chemical gloves), he was assisted by a second mechanical technician.the technician reports that he checked the valve was closed prior to gently slackening off the cap fitted to the downstream side of the valve. although he reports that he felt that he had satisfied himself that there was no pressure behind the cap, when he removed it there was what he describes a full flow of oil released.he was able to replace the cap, but in doing so he and his colleague were sprayed with oil. some of this oil fell through the gratings onto the dgs seal rack of hp1-2b compressors below. after replacing the cap, the technicians made a preliminary clean-up of the area before returning to the accommodation to inform the area authority, productions supervisor and re commissioning engineer of the incident.after showering they visited the medic for a quick check up.area around lp compressor wiped downbarriers erected around part of hp1-2b dgs rack pending clean-up due to slip hazard - no release to sea, all contained.

seal failure of hydraulic system an o-ring on the steering-drive cylinder of a new caterpillar scraper failed, spilling 2 ounces of hydraulic oil onto the ground. the operator immediately deployed the spill kit to absorb the oil. the operator contacted his supervisor and a sshe advisor was notified. an investigation was initiated.

felt pain in his upper back ip was in his accommodation cabin brushing his teeth when he felt pain across his back. the ip visited the medic who gave him paracatmol in order to reduce the pain. the ip was deemed fit for work. ip visited medic.supervisor informed ip not to over exert himself and to report back to him if pain got worse

category: lifting or moving loads, line strike
text: two crews were excavating a trench and struck a 1.1/4” pvc gas line and 1/2” pvc line - both empty two crews were excavating the trench to run cable and simultaneously struck a 1.1/4” white pvc gas line and 1/2” black pvc line. lines were empty.  actual of c1 is selected as damage is minor and easily fixed. potential is c1 as the lines were empty and would have been low pressure if operational.   crew stopped work immediatelycrew met up with the landowner on site and confirmed the following:the landowner was not aware of the ½” black pvc line. he mentioned sometimes these lines are used as markers when doing work and could have gotten buried, it is a thin wall thickness and there are bell ends on the line which suggests it is not pressure retaining. the 1.1/4” white line is a gas line. the landowner confirmed this by opening an upstream valve. the valve was closed at the time we were trenching. the landowner thought this gas line was the steel line marked between t-74 and t-75 on the drawing.we have asked the landowner to ensure all valves he has access to are closed and will repair the gas line.
ip tested +ve for covid-19 ip tested +ve on routine lft, subsequently confirmed by pcr line manager maintaining contact
ip tested + ip tested + none

employee positive for covid-19 employee was tested for covid-19 and returned a positive result on dec 09 covid 19 is home acquired. has no symptoms, nor has he had contact with other wood employees. although he has not had contact with the client in the last 72 hours, the client has been informed as immediate action. employee is in quarantine as per health ministry of buenos aires province guidelines.

individual tested positive for covid-19.  individual tested positive for covid-19. individual was self isolating due to a covid case in the household. individual  has not been to work for 20 days prior to the positive test.  none

lack of site required training. a last-minute site visit was requested for the campbell river substation project. an amecfw e&i employee from nanaimo was sent to site without having the required whmis or site safety training, as the dispatching office (nanaimo) thought neither credentials were required due to being escorted by a cat 5 safety watch. the deficiency was noted when the ppa hsse department reviewed the journey management plan and noted the lack of required pre-access training. the site visit was cancelled and the employee left the site. nanaimo hse coordinator coached on amecfw e&i's training requirements.

cameroonian ex-pat tested positive for covid-19. ip is 3/3 personnel to test positive after exposure to another employee.  ip was tested for covid-19 via rapid test after potentially coming into contact with another employee who tested positive on the 26th of march. ip has some mild symptoms and is currently in quarantine in vistamar apartment.  ip is currently in quarantine in vistamar apartment. due to medical history, an isos case file has been opened by the project manager in the event that symptoms progress. trident doctor will monitor condition and pm will remain in contact with ip for updates on condition. due to change in condition of ip and requirement for ip to be on oxygen, decision was made for med-evac process to be initiated by trident energy doctors. ip med-evaced to paris on the 13th of april where they are now receiving treatment. update 19.4.21 - ip is at home continuing positive recovery, no oxygen required and no further covid-19 symptoms. awaiting confirmation of case closure from isos.

hydro-vac truck mechanical failure a caterpillar hydro-vac truck was being used to pump water from the oily water sump on the northeast corner of pipe rack 1. the truck was parked on dura-base composite crane mats with the brakes engaged positioned on an incline. the driver was positioned in a safe location outside the truck operating the pump via a hand held remote when the truck slid down the mats and contacted the top of the concrete sump causing minor damage to the sump and truck bumper. it is believed at this time that there was a potential mechanical brake failure that caused this incident. workers involved with this task were positioned outside the strike zone of this event. area was secured and barricaded off. driver was taken to on-site medical for post incident screening. vac truck was removed from service to check mechanical integrity by a qualified mechanic.

non preventable, personal vehicle, no injuries wind swung open trash enclosure doors in office parking lot and hit employee car causing dents and scratches to right side of employee vehicle reported incident, no injuries.

category: foot or leg injury, slips & trips
text: fitter rolled his ankle on small cover at ground level. medical attention not required, pain subsided and the ip returned to work as normal. whilst doing routine maintenance work, ip stepped onto a small cover over some some cables and rolled his ankle.the ip had some small discomfort at the time, however felt that medical attention was not required and he continued to carry out his duties for the day. ip rested temporarily, then reported incident to his supervisor as soon as the employee had mobile reception. on the following day, the ip reported the ankle is fine and he has no restrictions on his mobility or fitness to work. the cover was in place and not ordinarily posing a trip hazard, the ip was not watching where he was placing his foot at the time.report only. reported the following day as the ip did not have mobile reception.

wg maint lngp.  flashing light on telehandler made contact with building door opening.  flashing light now inoperable. migrated from legacy cairs incident #31982backgroundlngp wg maintenance personnel (2 off) were transporting goods into building 5 utilising a telehandler. the personnel consisted of a telehandler operator and observer. the goods were brought to building 5 on a flatbed truck where the telehandler then unloads the truck and transports the goods into building 5 usually with guidance from the observer. once inside the building, the observer then moves the pallet of goods with a pallet trolley. building 5 is located in the warehouse area of the plant. the access to the building 5 door is on an incline with the road surface being compacted crushed rock. the road surface is a little uneven sometime requiring the telehandler operator to level the machine with the on-board levelling system. the telehandler is new to the workgroup (3 months old) and is taller than the one it replaces by approx. 350mm. the telehandler is left hand drive operated with the boom on the right. the flashing light sits atop of the cabin on the far left side and is the highest point of the machinethe telehandler operator was working with this machine on his last rotation (28 days) and this rotation. both the observer and telehandler operator are 10 days into their rotations. the telehandler operator has been operating these types of machines for some 16+ years. he has been working for wg since april 2015. the observer has been working for wg for over a year. risk assessment ejsa was in place for telehandler operations. ejsa identified potential hazard of “operating in proximity to structures”. ejsa identified the control to “implement controls on users / access (spotter)” and to “limit / monitor proximity to live equipment, cables and overhead hazards (spotter)”. the ejsa was adhered for the unloading of 2 pallets with telehandler operating under the guidance of the observerthe ejsa was not adhered to on the unloading of the third pallet when the observer was not available. this resulted in the incident where the flashing light made contact with the doorway opening on entering building 5incident detailsthat afternoon, the telehandler operator with the observer had arrived at building 5 to unload the truck of palleted goods. the observer was positioned so that he could see and identify any hazards with bringing the telehandler through the warehouse doors. on bringing through the first load, space was tight leaving approx. 100mm between the top of the building 5 door and the telehandler but was okay. the telehandler cleared the doorway and successfully entered building 5 and unloaded the pallet of goods. the observer then took the pallet away utilising a pallet trolley. this was the same process for the second load of palleted goods and again a successful unloading of the pallet. the third load was slightly unbalanced. the operator utilised the level function on the telehandler to level the load which in this case was to tilt to the right. this in-turn raises the left side if the machine. on entry to building 5, the observer was positioning goods on the pallet trolley. as the operator had successfully unloaded 2 loads prior, he deemed it safe to unload the third without guidance from the observer. on entering the building, the telehandler operator heard a cracking sound from above. he stopped the machine to inspect and found that the flashing light had made contact with the top of the doorway breaking the orange cover. no further damage was sustained. no contact was made with the telehandler. post incident actionthe observer returned and guided the telehandler operator to complete the remainder of the task successfully. the wg supervisor advised of the situation. telehandler operator a&d tested providing a negative sample (pass). migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

lngp projects.  wgpsn driver stopped their vehicle and left it on the service road in-between the mess and the green zone  where it later rolled, coming to a stop against a steel post resulting in damage to the vehicle and post. migrated from legacy cairs incident #28764lngp projects. wgpsn driver stopped their vehicle and left it on the service road in-between the mess and the green zone where it later rolled, coming to a stop against a steel post resulting in damage to the vehicle and post. no injury to driver. the driver had parked the vehicle behind the mess hall, exited,and did not apply the handbrake or leave the vehicle in gear. the driver did not appreciate the incline of the road he was on and when he left the vehicle it was stationary. after a short time the vehicle began to creep and picked up momentum resulting in it rolling down the road.at a previous toolbox talk it was emphasised to all the need to apply handbrake and leave the vehicle in gear. this action was adopted after a previous incident.the driver was taken for d & a testing, returned neg (-). migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

a worker hooked his front bumper on an obstruction while backing, damaging the bumper only. migrated from legacy cairs incident #30623a worker was backing his pickup and did not see a low obstruction which was at bumper height. as the worker backed in radius the front bumper hooked on the obstruction causing it to bend outward. no additional damage occurred and the speed was below 5 mph. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

one employee communicated a positive confirmation for covid-19  one employee reported a confirmed positive test for covid-19 to site management. the employee has been in isolation since august 26th.  wood is identifying those who may have worked in proximity.  appropriate notifications have been completed.

an employee was operating a cat skid steer and moving stone to spread around some pipe.  while spreading stone the employee contacted a pipe with the bucket of the skid steer. migrated from legacy cairs incident #29041on 3/16/2016 at 11:30 am, kelchner employee john kielbasa was operating skid steer r-289-14. john was removing stone from a pile located beside two parallel 24 inch gas lines. after filling the bucket with stone john navigated the skid steer parallel to the 24 inch gas lines and proceeded to take the load to kelchner laborer ulises mendoza. just before dumping the load of stone john got slightly stuck on a small pile of stone. john moved the joystick to the left and the skid steer didn’t move to where he wanted it to move. then suddenly the skid steer became unstuck and quickly moved to the left. during this quick movement the bucket of the skid steer contacted the 24 inch discharge line. ulises was standing slightly right of the skid steer, near a cross over pipe and he observed the contact with the pipe and skid steer bucket. kelchner laborer darrick myren was standing 8 feet back behind ulises and he observed the bucket of skid steer contact the pipe. after witnessing the event darrick went to the job trailer and reported the incident to foreman ryan sine, then ryan reported then reported the incident to foreman kevin myers. john continued to work after the incident and did not let any manager know what he had done. about 45 minutes after the event, during lunch john explained the incident to foreman kevin myers. at 12:15 pm. kevin called eurkea hunter inspector rusty williams. kevin and rusty then went to inspect the 24 inch discharge line. after filling off the paint from the pipe, the damage was determined to be 3/16 inch in diameter and 1/16 of inch in depth. the damage warranted an x-ray of the area.  during my investigation i discovered that for over 2 weeks the crew had been scattering stone around the pad. during that time the skid steer was used to move stone as close as possible to all areas of the compressor station. laborers with shovels would then spread the stone evenly over the area. the laborers were also responsible to spot the operator in areas where there was potential to contact pipe or related compressor components. during my interview with john i asked him why he didn’t immediately notify his supervisor after the event had occurred, john explained that “he didn’t believe the damage to pipe was that severe”. in our conversation john let me know that prior to the incident he transported two other loads of stone parallel to the 24 inch lines. when i asked john if he was ever concerned about being within 1-2 feet of 24 inch gas lines with heavy equipment, john explained that “he wasn’t concerned at all and he felt comfortable around the lines”. prior to my interview with john he was taken to wheeling corporate health for a post incident drug/alcohol test and both tests were negative. after my interview with john he was terminated for failure to immediately notify his supervisor after contacting the line and failure to stop work.  onsite a safety stand-down was conducted to review the incident that had occurred. the meeting emphasized the pressure within these gas lines and potential severity with a broken line. the meeting also emphasized immediately reporting any incident to the onsite foreman. an onsite policy was implemented that no heavy equipment would be used within 6 feet of gas lines or compressor station components. during our meeting the pipe was being x-rayed. the x-ray tech confirmed that the integrity of the pipe was not compromised and was still within code. eurkea hunter accepted the x-ray techs determination and the damaged area will be recoated with primer. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

employee started breathing heavily and ems was summoned. employee was installing panels throughout the day at block 2. at the end of the shift the employee was taken from block 2 to block 4 where the family’s vehicle was parked. the employee was waiting for their family members to arrive at the block to leave for the day. while waiting the employee started to feel cold and started breathing heavy. at that point the ambulance was summoned to block 4. the ambulance personnel evaluated the employee, after that the employee refused further treatment. employee then went home for the day. employee was instructed to obtain a medical release form prior to returning to work.

lower back strain employee reported discomfort in lower back after lifting a 3-ton come-a-long on scaffold. employee stated that the incident happened at 8 am on 1-16-20, however he did not report it to his supervisor until near the end of shift. ie was evaluated, treated, and released back to work without restrictions by the on-site medic.

category: lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general
text: flat bed van struck scaffold tube and damaged tube - no structural damage to scaffold flat bed lorry was reversed from road 8 onto avenue h when the driver pulled forward back onto road 8  to the contacted the scaffold tube that was on the corner, bending the tube. the scaffold tube was not part of the structure but was put in place to protect personnel from coming into contact with over sailed transoms. scaffold tube removed and scaffold amended, incident reported late and therefore team only have the scaffold tube as evidence.informed all of the supervision that if an incident occurs to leave the site as is and report it. if the structure is compromised then make it safe but leave it all in place to be seen by the investigation team.

category: dropped object or material, near miss
text: nurse received a needlestick injury following administering vaccinations. migrated from legacy cairs incident #39759employee and their spouse attended the internal clinic to receive travel immunisations. the employee's appointment was at 10:45 with his spouse directly thereafter. at circa 11:45 the nurse injected the spouse in the left arm and returned the empty needle and contents to the dish, then followed by the right arm. on completion the nurse carried the dish with the needled to the sharps bin but missed the bin resulting in the needle entering her foot.the couple left the wood building around 11:55.the internal clinic doctor became aware of the incident around 2pm. the nurse had taken action to expel blood from the puncture site and cleaned with hot soapy water.the doctor insisted the nurse attend hospital and escalate the incident through their management team. this has now since taken place with the nurse being provided with post-exposure prophylaxis(pep) an antiretroviral medicinesto prevent hiv infection.investigation ongoing.update: 19/10/18following witness statements, interviews, and demonstration of the alleged event, the investigation team have concluded that there is inconclusive evidence to support a needlestick injury occurring. however, the team do acknowledge that the needle dropped to the floor whilst unsheathed. on this basis the investigation team have taken the decision to downgrade this event to a near miss (nm). the potential has been downgraded to low as should there have been evidence to support the needlestick injury, the chance of their having been blood in the needle is small and any adverse effects from such would have required the patient who was receiving the immunization to be a carrier of a blood borne virus, there is no evidence to suggest this was the case in this event. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description
struck against moving part of machinery or equipment an employee was slicing meat and suffered a partial amputation to the right middle finger.

fall on same level due to tripping, unspecified an employee was walking into work when she either tripped on a curb or walked into a hole in the grass and fell. the employee broke her humerus bone and was admitted to the hospital for surgery.

injured by slipping or swinging object held by injured worker on march 20, 2015, at approximately 11:00 p.m., an employee was using a core drill to remove anchors from the face of the bluestone dam in hinton, west virginia. a 1/4" to 3/8" rope became entangled in the 3" core bit. the employee's left arm was pulled into the rotating bit, which resulted in fractures of the radius and ulna.
overexertion in lifting-single episode an employee was removing an ems gurney with an injured patient on it and felt a "twinge" in his neck.

contact with objects and equipment, unspecified on or about january 30, 2015, an employee suffered an amputation of three fingertips while operating a rolling mill machine.

caught in running equipment or machinery, unspecified an employee was starting the hammer mill line from the control station. once the start button is activated a short delay occurs before the machine starts moving. the employee then ran down two flights of stairs, lifted the rubber cover on the chute for the elevator bucket, and was caught by the equipment as it started to move. the employee sustained fractures to the ulna and radius in his right forearm and the right index finger was amputated to the second knuckle.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was helping a crew perform a dry run for placing concrete slab when his hand was caught in a wrench drive shaft that engaged, causing a right hand laceration and finger dislocation.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation on january 16, 2019, at approximately 3:35 p.m., a machine operator was working to run normal production on the ravioli forming machine. the employee was tasked with continuously supplying (feeding) the filling into the machine and to start/stop the machine to make small production adjustments to the product. at some point during production, the injured employee contacted moving components inside the machine and sustained an amputation, without bone loss, to the middle fingertip of the left hand.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee was dumping a manual trash hopper. the hopper pinched four of her fingers, causing injuries that required surgery.

category: head or face injury, slips & trips
text: fall on same level, n.e.c.  an employee was on a ramp pulling on a cargo strap when the strap broke and the employee fell backward striking his head on the ground and causing a loss of consciousness.

category: foot or leg injury, hand or arm injury
text: struck against moving part of machinery or equipment an employee cut a piece of wood on a table saw and was reaching to grab the leftover stock when the employee's thumb struck the saw blade, severing a tendon.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee lifted the tongue of a generator to move it when his finger was caught/pinched between the jack and tongue. this resulted in a partial amputation of the right index fingertip.

category: weather related issue, hand or arm injury
text: struck by or caught in swinging door or gate an employee was pushing a dumpster into an enclosure. a gust of wind caught the enclosure door and slammed the door into the dumpster catching the employee's left hand middle finger resulting in amputation.

explosion, n.e.c. an employee was using a tool to install a thread protector on a tubular when the tool's lithium battery exploded in the non-mag tubular, sending up debris and chemicals that struck employees on the rig floor. an employee was hospitalized with face and wrist burns.

part of occupantís body caught between vehicle and other object in nonroadway transport incident a forklift operator was using the forklift to take pallets from receiving docks to a reserve storage location. the forklift reversed and his left little finger was pinched between the forklift and a rack, causing an amputation of the fingertip with bone loss.

fall or jump from vehicle in normal operation, roadway an employee had just serviced a portable toilet and stepped on the passenger side of the truck. while the truck was moving, he fell off and injured his head.

category: foot or leg injury, vehicle incident general, slips & trips
text: fall on same level due to tripping, unspecified an employee was exiting her mail delivery vehicle when her feet became tangled underneath the vehicle and she fell, fracturing both ankles.

category: fall from or working at height issue, head or face injury
text: other fall to lower level 11 to 15 feet  an employee was descending a railcar and fell approximately 12 feet. his pfas was not anchored at the time. the employee was hospitalized for head trauma.

category: lifting or moving loads, general injury
text: pedestrian struck by vehicle in nonroadway area, unspecified on december 4, 2018, an employee was dismantling and installing pallet uprights. the employee was struck by a narrow-aisle forklift being operated by the host employer luk usa llc. the employee sustained a fractured hip and injury to the pelvic area.

category: foot or leg injury, slips & trips
text: fall on same level, n.e.c.  an employee fell and twisted an ankle while setting up an extension ladder.

category: dropped object or material, hand or arm injury
text: struck by falling part of powered vehicle still attached an employee was helping to set a concrete lid weighing a couple hundred pounds for an electrical box in place. one end of a length of steel chain was attached to a steel loop (hasp) embedded in the concrete lid.  the employee attempted to attach the other end of this chain to a steel loop (hasp) on the back (underside) of an excavator bucket when the excavator boom unexpectedly dropped, pinning the employee's right thumb between the bottom of the excavator bucket and the concrete lid. his right thumb was amputated at a point between the first and second knuckle.

category: hand or arm injury, slips & trips
text: caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was moving straws from one side to the other of a hopper when the employee's hand slipped into the conveyor, resulting in a right middle finger amputation.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment an employee was trying to dislodge a mattress that was stuck on a wooden pallet. the forklift that had loaded the mattress moved to the side, freeing it and causing it to pinch the employee's ring finger. the fingertip was amputated.
overexertion in lifting-single episode an employee was trying to lift a granite countertop out of a pick-up truck bed when he twisted and injured his lower back.

contact with hot objects or substances an employee disconnected what he thought was a steam hose but was actually a molten asphalt hose. the molten asphalt splashed his chest and arms, causing second degree burns.

compressed or pinched by shifting objects or equipment a maintenance employee was unloading metal bed frames from a truck at an off-site scrap yard. his finger became caught in the bed frame and/or caught between the bed frame and the side of the truck, partially amputating his left first fingertip. he was hospitalized.

category: head or face injury, foot or leg injury, vehicle incident general, slips & trips
text: fall on same level due to tripping over an object  an employee was pushing a cart of clothes when her foot hit the carpet, causing her to fall forward to the floor. she broke both arms and her nose.

struck by discharged or flying object, n.e.c. an employee was driving a john deere gator truck on a gravel road at the worksite while holding a spray wand, which was attached to the 25-gallon spray tank. as she curbed to the right, she did not realize that the hose unraveled and caught the tires, causing the wand to move and strike her right eye. this resulted in the loss of an eye.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was operating a press to stamp a fender. he was attempting to remove the fender when the cam crushed his right index finger between the part and the cam, resulting in a fingertip amputation.
contact with hot objects or substances an employee was splashed with hot tar after a machinery malfunction.

category: general injury, fall from or working at height issue, slips & trips
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified while unloading freight from a semi-trailer, an employee fell off the back of the trailer to the ground below, suffering a broken rib and collapsed lung.

category: back injury, general illness or health issue
text: overexertion involving outside sources, unspecified an employee was stocking milk cartons in a dairy cooler when he felt a strain in his back. he was hospitalized for hernia surgery.
